tailwind css it saves you time and allows you to build

much into css or you know frontend or web um oftentimes what people will do as
they build out web pages or web apps is ship like the same line of css
10 000 times across an n number of different classes or ident or css declaration sets so for
example um you know a classic css rule is display
flex that will allow you to create a box that puts things side by side um if you have like five different boxes
and you want each of them to have things side by side you write display flex for each of them um most often and you can
maybe abstract this away but by the nature of css you're bound to repeat a few rules sometimes tailwind
has an atomic model where literally one class maps to one css rule
and that way that css rule is written and shipped one time um your users download it one time
um and it kind of just works across the whole app as expected but then you might
think if it's one class name per css rule that's going to be a massive css file
but at build time before you ship your final product it will literally look at what you're using and only ship those
classes and those css rules um because tail and css is opinionated it also
gives you powerful auto completion uh out of the box uh directly in your
